I am somewhat confused about the decision to abolish the igniter. I understand that parts can have failures too, but "a delicate dance between fuel power head and oxygen power head" or else "melt or explode the preburners" sounds like a place where things can go wrong more easily than a well tested part.

I'm curious if & how the chamber pressure could be increased substantially. A naive view would involve thicker stronger walls of the chamber, throat, nozzle, and injector array, plus more powerful pumps. But thicker -> heavier, which also dramatically affects material cooling, and its not obvious how the turbopumps could be made more powerful without going to a two stage design, which would be extremely complicated. Would, for example, 400 or even 500 bar be worth the cost? This would also require rather different nozzles, either longer or wider or both.
Hmm. Now I'm pondering a hybrid partial-aerospike plus classic bell design where combustion is done partially inside the nozzle. Hard to explain in a short comment, and IANA Rocket engineer so I'm "talking through my hat".

The analysis of the increase of work is a little bit misleading because is just at the beginning.  I don't know that I could do better without math, so there is that. In reality, as the rocket mass diminished stuff get a little bit more nuanced.  We are pulling the same mass.  Take the final speed of a small rocket without atmosphere, and you will get a term like -gt under constant gravity approximation, what you are changing when you change the mass flow is the time you expend fighting gravity (looks like. e * ln(Mf/Mi). -g*t)  at the end, the dominant term is not the gt but the other and the results are not as spectacular as he said, by a wide margin.  Also, you are not trying to get max up-down velocity but a tangential one to get into orbit,, so the. effect of increasing the mass flow is even lower.  Maybe someone has the ability to explaint it without math? maybe with a graph or something?

Actually, while it's true that increasing to a T/W ratio of 1.5:1 is 20% more than a T/W ratio of 1.25:1 and that results in a doubling of the net acceleration that is only true at the very beginning -- as the fuel burns off the acceleration increases for both but the net acceleration difference declines throughout the burn -- by the end of the burn as the propellent is almost used up the acceleration advantage would decline to about 20%.  It is not uncommon to shut some of the engines down before seperation to keep the net accel down to about 4g and with more total thrust with Raptor 2's they would need to shutdown some engines earlier.  You could throttle down but that lowers the efficiency as it lower chamber pressure.

The reason SpaceX is so successful with their designs today is the same reason why the Soviets led the first half of the space race. Traditional American rocket engineering goes through an extreme level of testing of every individual component, so they basically know how it's going to fly before it ever takes off, and the cost-plus-contract funding tends to slow things down and drive up cost. The Soviets had a hardware-based approach where it was built, and usually tested only in all-up flight, and as a consequence, they tended to have a deeper understanding of the "previously unknowns", and it was highly successful before Brezhnev pulled a Nixon and killed a lot of space program funding. SpaceX uses the same hardware-based approach. The Russians refer to it as "Ah Kalyenki", meaning a piece of paper and pencil on the knee. They've blown up a LOT of rockets and engines, and because of that they have a very intimate understanding of their hardware. Much more so than NASA ever did or likely ever will do.

To be fair, what Tim was talking about in terms of doubling (for the Merlin now versus when it first came out) is an aggregate of thrust to weight ratio to specific impulse. The merlin engines aggregate doubled because the thrust effectively doubled (47 tons to 96 tons) while the weight and ISP remained relatively the same (+/- a few percent). Raptor 1 however, weighing 2000 kg, with a thrust of 185 Tons and an ISP of 330 seconds, doubling that aggregate would be synonymous with reducing the weight to 1000 kg or increasing thrust to 370 tons or increasing ISP to 660 seconds. For simplicity's sake, the aggregate (of Raptor 1) being thrust (185) divided by weight (2000) multiplied by ISP (330) would give you an aggregate of 30.525. The aggregate of Raptor 2 is 47.00625 or a roughly 54% increase in aggregate. To get a 100% increase or an aggregate of 61.05 (vs Raptor 1) would be something like a weight of 1350 kg, thrust of 255 tons and an ISP of 318 or a combination of changes thereof. If the goal is 250 tons of thrust, weight would need to come down to 1365.85 kg with no change to the ISP (327) which I believe is doable (~235 kg of weight savings).

(As a side note, you cannot compare aggregates across differing engines IE the aggregate of Merlin to aggregate of Raptor to determine which one is the "better" engine. While a higher value does mean "better", it is better in respect to a previous version of itself. Merlin (specifically 1D) has a higher aggregate due to it's crazy thrust to weight ratio when compared to the Raptor 2. Merlin engines cannot power the booster or starship because they have a higher aggregate is what I am getting at.)

I think it is possible for SpaceX to get there the how is the unknown. Tim stated material sciences as a factor and I think that is be the biggest factor. Graphene, or a derivative of, could be used to make a newer version of Raptor engines stronger while being of lesser weight as one example but only if graphene could be produced competitively price wise. Changing the mechanics is a trade-off, expansion ratio to ISP being the one talked about in the video above. Changing the mechanics without changing materials is usually a <5% change in overall efficiency or aggregate as seen in the use case above. We have seen SpaceX innovate heavily in this area, specifically the alloy of steel used for the construction of the Starship + Booster and the many known and unknown alloys used in the Raptor family of engines.

Lastly, one thing that is not mentioned in the video and should be, is the weight decrease to Raptor 2 is partially semantic. Some of the parts were moved from the engine to the mounting plate for reliability and ease of maintenance. While the engine itself did decrease in weight, the weight of the booster increased, negating some of the weight savings which is not mentioned. This by no means undermines what SpaceX is doing but context is needed to fully understand what is truly happening. Just like landing legs being taken away from the booster and stage 0 getting a pair of reinforced chopsticks to catch the booster, some of the mass reduction is not simply the mass disappearing due to efficiency gains but rather being reallocated elsewhere.

In your last Video about Raptor 2, Elon said that increasing the area under the trust-time-curve ist important. But I can't see how this could be more important then the isp, I mean, both seem to be unimportant for me. Elon said Raptor is a force generator, which is right, but what he actually wants to know is the effect which the force has on the rocket, he can't stick to just the force. This effect, the acceleration, depends on the mass of the rocket and this mass is changing.
Meaning, a force at the end of the rockets burn time will have a greater effect then the same force applied at the launch pad. The force-time-graph doesn't show this.
Instead the force ÷ mass (acceleration) -time-curve matters. The area under the curve is then your velocity (minus the losses of course) - a physical unit very useful to calculate with.
